titleInfo.title: McKinley High School Oral History Project: History of the School
titleInfo.subTitle: Adolph Jerome Byrd oral history interview, 1995

name.description: Adolph Jerome Byrd was born January 22, 1922, in Shreveport, La. He attended McKinley High School in Baton Rouge, La., from 1935 to 1942, often dropping out to work and support himself financially. Byrd attended Louisiana Negro Normal and Industrial School (now Grambling State University) beginning in 1942, but left to serve in World War II. He returned there after the war and earned a degree in elementary education in 1949. Byrd later completed master and doctoral degrees and taught in Louisiana for over 30 years.

subject.topic: African American high school students--Louisiana--Baton Rouge.

mods.abstract: Byrd discusses his attendance at McKinley High School, including academics, sports, activities, influential teachers, older students, and graduates; his struggle to complete high school because of the need to drop out for work; the role of the community in raising children; disciplinary action he and other children received when they misbehaved; the lack of discipline and respect among young people today; and the need to rehabilitate nonviolent criminals.
